Stretch into it gradually. Don't force depth.
Your current level. Straight arms, flat body.
Builds the pushing base for lever control

CRITICAL: Build German hang flexibility FIRST. Don't rush this.
Shoulders are in a vulnerable position - progress slowly
Bicep tendons are stressed - warm up thoroughly
Skin the cat is the best drill - do it every session
If shoulders feel strained, reduce depth or go back a progression

Body must be rigid - if hips pike or sag, go easier progression

Rest fully between sets (2-3 minutes) - these are neurologically demanding
Pick the progression level where you can hold 10-15 seconds with good form
When you can hold 3x15-20 seconds, try the next progression
Don't train to failure - stop when form breaks down

Hold legs at 90 degrees. Shoulders active.

Keep shoulders active (not passive hanging) during leg work

Straight arms always. If arms bend, you're too advanced for that progression.

Focus on form over speed, especially as fatigue sets in

name: Heavy Duty: Chest & Back
description: Classic Mentzer chest/back split using pre-exhaustion. Isolate the target muscle first, then hit it with a compound while fatigued. This forces the target muscle to fail before your arms give out.

exercises.notes: ISOLATION: Pec deck or cable fly. Squeeze hard at contraction. 4-2-4 tempo. To FAILURE.
COMPOUND: Immediately into press (no rest). Chest pre-fatigued = chest fails first. To FAILURE.
ISOLATION: Pullover or straight-arm pulldown. Feel the lats stretch. 4-2-4 tempo. To FAILURE.
COMPOUND: Immediately into row (no rest). Lats pre-fatigued = back fails before biceps. To FAILURE.
Only if you have more in the tank. 1 set, absolute failure, rest-pause if needed.
Only if you have more in the tank. 1 set, absolute failure.

tips: PRE-EXHAUST: Isolation exercise first tires the target muscle. The compound then forces it to fail before synergists.
NO REST between isolation and compound - this is one continuous superset
FAILURE on both exercises. If you can do more, the weight was too light.
WAIT 5-7 DAYS before training chest/back again
This workout should take ~25-30 min if done with proper intensity

name: Heavy Duty: Consolidation
description: Mentzer's famous 'Ideal Routine' - the ultimate in training economy. Just 5 exercises, hitting every major muscle group. Only train this 1x per week (or even less). Maximum results, minimum time.

exercises.name: Mentzer's Most Controversial Routine
exercises.notes: This is HIGH INTENSITY training taken to its logical conclusion. 5 exercises, 1 set each, to absolute failure. Train ONCE per week or LESS. Sounds too little? Try it - the intensity makes up for the volume.
Just enough to break a sweat. Save energy for the working sets.
1 warmup set. 1 ALL-OUT set to absolute failure. Full range of motion. 4-2-4 tempo.
1 warmup set. 1 ALL-OUT set. Full stretch at bottom. 4-2-4 tempo. To FAILURE.
1 warmup set. 1 ALL-OUT set. Squeeze shoulder blades. 4-2-4 tempo. To FAILURE.
1 working set. Full range of motion. 4-2-4 tempo. To FAILURE.
The grand finale. 1 working set. Full body engagement. 4-2-4 tempo. To FAILURE.

tips: This routine is NOT for beginners - you need to know how to truly train to failure
5 sets total. That's it. If you need more, you're not training hard enough.
WAIT 7+ DAYS between sessions. Mentzer trained some clients only once every 2 weeks.
Progressive overload: add weight or reps each session. If you can't progress, you're overtraining.
This works because intensity trumps volume. 1 set at 100% effort beats 10 sets at 50%.

name: What is Heavy Duty Training?
description: An educational introduction to Mike Mentzer's Heavy Duty system. Learn the principles before starting the program. This explains WHY you train less but harder.

exercises.name: The Man Behind Heavy Duty
exercises.notes: Mike Mentzer (1951-2001) was a champion bodybuilder and philosopher of training. He won the 1978 Mr. Universe with a perfect score. After competing, he developed Heavy Duty - a training system based on scientific principles and logic, not gym bro science.

exercises.name: Train HARDER, Not Longer
exercises.notes: The stimulus for muscle growth is INTENSITY - how hard you train, not how much. One set taken to true muscular failure stimulates growth just as well as 3-5 sets. More sets just add fatigue without additional benefit.

exercises.name: What 'Failure' Really Means
exercises.notes: FAILURE means you cannot complete another rep with proper form, no matter how hard you try. Not 'this is getting hard' - true failure. When you reach this point, you've triggered the adaptive response. Anything beyond is unnecessary.

sets.name: Principle 3: Recovery is Where Growth Happens

exercises.name: You Don't Grow in the Gym
exercises.notes: Training damages muscle. RECOVERY is when you grow. Most people overtrain - they return to the gym before fully recovering, making zero progress. Heavy Duty prescribes 4-7+ days between training the same muscle. Sounds crazy? Try it.

exercises.name: Tire the Target Muscle First
exercises.notes: Problem: On bench press, your triceps often fail before your chest. Solution: Pre-exhaust. Do an isolation exercise (pec fly) immediately before the compound (bench). Your chest is pre-fatigued, so it fails first during the press.

exercises.name: The Only Way to Know It's Working
exercises.notes: If you're getting stronger (more weight or more reps), you're growing. If not, something's wrong - usually overtraining. Log every workout. Add weight when you hit the top of your rep range. Small increments add up to big gains.

exercises.name: Slow and Controlled
exercises.notes: 4 seconds lifting (concentric), 2 second squeeze at contraction, 4 seconds lowering (eccentric). No bouncing, no momentum. This ensures the muscle does ALL the work and maximizes time under tension. If you can't control it, it's too heavy.

exercises.name: How Often to Train
exercises.notes: BEGINNER: Full body 2x/week (e.g., Mon/Thu). INTERMEDIATE: 2-way split, each 1x/week. Day 1: Chest/Back. Day 2: Legs/Shoulders/Arms. ADVANCED: Consolidation routine 1x every 5-7 days. Yes, really. More rest = more growth.

tips: Start with the 'Intro Full Body' workout to learn the techniques
Keep a training log - track weight, reps, and how you felt
If you're not progressing after 2-3 weeks, you're training too often
Eat enough protein and sleep 7-8 hours - recovery requires resources
This system challenges everything you've been told. Give it 8 weeks before judging.

name: Heavy Duty: Intro Full Body
description: A beginner-friendly introduction to Mike Mentzer's Heavy Duty system. Learn the principles: train to failure, use slow controlled reps, and keep volume low. This workout hits all major muscle groups with 1-2 sets each.

exercises.name: Read Before Starting
exercises.notes: Heavy Duty training means: 1) SLOW reps (4 sec up, 4 sec down), 2) Go to COMPLETE failure on working sets, 3) Rest 2-3 min between sets, 4) Only 1-2 working sets per exercise. Quality over quantity!
Just get blood flowing - save energy for working sets
Warmup: 1 light set of 12. Then 1 ALL-OUT set to failure. 4-2-4 tempo.
Isolation first: 1 set to failure. 4-2-4 tempo. Feel the chest burn.
Immediately into compound press. Chest is pre-fatigued, so it fails first!
1 warmup set, then 1 ALL-OUT set. Squeeze shoulder blades. 4-2-4 tempo.
1 working set to failure. Control the negative. 4-2-4 tempo.
Immediately to triceps. No rest. Both to failure.

tips: TEMPO IS KEY: 4 seconds up, 2 second squeeze, 4 seconds down
FAILURE MEANS FAILURE: When you can't move the weight with good form, you're done
REST LONG: 2-3 minutes between exercises - you need full recovery for max effort
WAIT 4-7 DAYS before training these muscles again - recovery is when you grow
Log your weights and reps - progress means adding weight or reps over time

name: Heavy Duty: Legs
description: Mentzer's brutal leg workout. Pre-exhaust quads with leg extensions, then destroy them with leg press or squats. Minimal sets, maximum intensity. Your legs will thank you (eventually).

exercises.notes: Light movement to get blood flowing. Hip circles, leg swings.
1 LIGHT warmup set on leg extension. Just to feel the muscle.
LEG EXTENSION: Squeeze at top for 2 sec. 4-2-4 tempo. All the way to FAILURE.
LEG PRESS or SQUAT: Immediately (no rest). Quads are pre-fatigued. Deep range of motion. To FAILURE.
1 working set to failure. Squeeze at contraction. 4-2-4 tempo.
Full stretch at bottom, hard squeeze at top. 1 set to failure. Hold top for 2 sec each rep.

tips: The quad pre-exhaust superset is BRUTAL - your quads will be screaming before compound
On leg press/squat: go deep, control the negative, explode (but controlled) on positive
You may need to reduce weight significantly on the compound since quads are pre-fatigued
WAIT AT LEAST 5-7 DAYS before training legs again - they need recovery time
If you can walk normally after this workout, you didn't go hard enough

name: Heavy Duty: Rest-Pause Technique
description: Learn Mentzer's rest-pause method for going beyond failure. Hit failure, rest 10 seconds, continue. This extends the set past your normal limits and triggers maximum growth stimulus.

exercises.name: The Rest-Pause Technique
exercises.notes: REST-PAUSE: 1) Perform reps until failure. 2) Rest 10-15 seconds (rack the weight). 3) Continue for 2-4 more reps until failure again. 4) Optional: repeat one more time. This extends time under tension and recruits more muscle fibers.
REST-PAUSE: Go to failure (~8-12 reps). Rack weight, rest 10 sec. Continue to failure (2-4 reps). Rest 10 sec. Final push to failure.
REST-PAUSE: Go to failure. Rest 10 sec. Continue to failure. Rest 10 sec. Final push.
REST-PAUSE: Same technique. Keep form strict even when fatigued.
REST-PAUSE: Failure, 10 sec rest, failure, 10 sec rest, final failure. Feel the pump.
REST-PAUSE: Same technique. Lock out fully on each rep.

tips: REST-PAUSE lets you do more work in less time with the same weight
The 10-second rest allows partial ATP recovery - just enough for a few more reps
Use machines for rest-pause - easier to rack/unrack weight safely
Don't use rest-pause on deadlifts or squats as a beginner - form breaks down
This is ONE extended set - counts as your working set for that muscle group

name: Heavy Duty: Shoulders & Arms
description: Mentzer's shoulder and arm routine. Pre-exhaust delts with lateral raises, then press. Arms get supersetted for maximum pump with minimum volume. Short, intense, effective.

exercises.notes: LATERAL RAISE: Strict form, no swinging. Pause at top. 4-2-4 tempo. To FAILURE.
SHOULDER PRESS: Immediately (no rest). Delts pre-fatigued = shoulders fail before triceps. To FAILURE.
1 set to failure. Squeeze shoulder blades together. 4-2-4 tempo.
BICEPS: Full range of motion. Squeeze at top. 4-2-4 tempo. To FAILURE.
TRICEPS: Immediately (no rest). Lock out fully. 4-2-4 tempo. To FAILURE.
Only if you have more. Rest-pause if needed: hit failure, rest 10 sec, continue to failure again.
Same technique. 1 more superset, both to failure.

tips: Lateral raises: keep strict form - if you're swinging, the weight is too heavy
Pre-exhaust on shoulders means you'll use less weight on press - that's the point
Arms superset = biceps to failure, immediately triceps to failure. No rest.
REST-PAUSE technique: at failure, rest 10 sec, continue until failure again
Total arm volume is only 2-4 sets - but each set is 100% effort

name: Jump Rope: Cardio Blast
description: Pure cardio conditioning with the jump rope. Intervals of high intensity followed by active recovery. Expect to be breathing hard.

exercises.notes: ALL OUT - drive those knees up!
Active recovery - keep moving but easy pace
Fast feet! Max speed you can maintain
Catch your breath - keep rope moving
2 minutes straight - don't stop! Find a sustainable pace and push through.
Very easy, let heart rate come down

tips: During work intervals: PUSH IT. This is cardio conditioning.
During recovery: keep the rope moving but take it easy
If you trip, reset immediately and keep going
Stay light on your feet - heavy landings waste energy
Breathe! Don't hold your breath during intense sections

name: Jump Rope: Footwork Drills
description: Focus on foot coordination, agility, and movement patterns. Great for athletes who want to improve their footwork for sports like boxing, basketball, or tennis.

exercises.notes: Hip rotation - keep upper body stable

tips: Footwork is about CONTROL - don't rush the patterns
Keep movements small and precise, especially when learning
If a pattern is too hard, slow down the rope speed
Think 'light and quick' - minimize ground contact time
Great for boxers, basketball players, tennis players - any sport needing quick feet

name: Jump Rope: Mixed Session
description: A balanced jump rope workout with warmup, skills practice, footwork drills, and cardio finisher. Shuffle to randomize which workout you get - each one focuses on different areas.
tips: Hit shuffle to get a random workout variation
Each variation focuses on different aspects: skills, cardio, footwork, or progressions
Keep your rope sized correctly - handles should reach your armpits when standing on the middle

name: Jump Rope: Progression Practice
description: Structured skill progressions from basics to intermediate. Each block builds on the previous. Perfect for beginners working toward consistent jumping and learning new skills.

exercises.notes: 10 consecutive jumps - reset if you trip
Try for 30 - this is your baseline
5 jumps on right leg - it's OK to trip!
Heel tap, toe tap - go slow
1 minute straight. Count your trips. Fewer trips = progress!

tips: PROGRESSIONS: Master each level before moving to the next
Tripping is NORMAL - reset quickly and keep going
If you can't do 20 consecutive basic jumps yet, practice that before moving on
Track your progress: How many consecutive jumps can you do?
Practice 10-15 minutes daily for fastest improvement

name: Jump Rope: Skills Focus
description: Work on jump rope tricks and techniques. Practice criss-cross, double unders, and other skills with plenty of rest between attempts. Focus on form, not cardio.

exercises.notes: Relaxed, shift weight side to side
Loosen up your arms and shoulders
Attempt 3-5 criss-crosses. Reset if you trip.
Active recovery - swing side to side
Attempt 1-3 double unders. Focus on wrist speed.

tips: Skills practice is about QUALITY, not cardio - rest as much as you need
If you keep tripping, slow down and focus on the arm/foot timing
For criss-cross: cross at hip level, not chest level
For double unders: it's wrist speed, not jumping higher
Film yourself to see what you're doing wrong

name: 100 Rep Daily KB Challenge (@gymfiesta)
description: 100 reps of 6 kettlebell exercises — halos, side swings, high pulls, swings, tricep extensions, and rows. Do it daily with a light bell. High volume, full body, posture and conditioning focused.

exercises.notes: Side-to-side swings across the body. 4x25 = 100 total. Use core rotation.
High pull variation — elbows high, shrug at top. 4x25 = 100 total.
Standard two-handed swings. Squeeze glutes hard at top. 4x25 = 100 total.
Tricep extension variation — lower behind head, extend. Elbows stay close. 4x25 = 100 total.
~12-13 per side per set. 4 sets = 100 total. Pull with back, squeeze.

tips: Use a LIGHT kettlebell — this is 600 total reps
Break each 100 into 4x25 or 5x20 as needed
Designed to be done daily — not a max effort session
Focus on form over speed at this volume
Credit: @gymfiesta

name: 20-Min KB Full Body (@Asgooch)
description: Only got 20 minutes and one kettlebell? Swings, goblet squats, rows, goblet press — 10 reps each, 5 rounds. @Asgooch says do this 3x/week to get fit from home.

exercises.notes: Single arm, 10 per side. Pull with back.
Goblet press — both hands, KB at chest to overhead.

tips: 20 minutes, one kettlebell — that's all you need
Do this 3x per week for general fitness
No rest between exercises, 60 seconds between rounds
Perfect for home, hotel, or outdoor training
Credit: @Asgooch

name: Athletic Alternating KB Circuit (@Asgooch)
description: Build an athletic physique with one kettlebell. Everything alternates — cleans, squats, presses — adding core stability on top of the strength work. Finish with offset pushups on the bell.

exercises.notes: Alternating cleans — switch hands each rep. 12 total.
Alternating goblet squat — hold with one hand at chest, switch each rep. 12 total.
Offset pushups — one hand on the KB handle, one on the ground. Alternate sides.

tips: One kettlebell, no gym needed
The alternating pattern challenges core stability more than bilateral work
All exercises x12 (6 per side for unilateral)
Credit: @Asgooch

name: Athletic KB Lunge Variations (@sculptherbody)
description: Four dynamic kettlebell + lunge combos for athletic performance. Lunge clean-to-press, split pass thrust, lunge snatch, and step-back swings. Each combines lower-body with explosive upper-body work.

exercises.notes: Lunge clean-to-press: lunge forward while cleaning, press overhead as you stand. Each side.
Split pass thrust: hold split stance, pass/thrust KB between legs. Focus on stability.
Lunge snatch: reverse lunge + snatch from floor to overhead in one motion. Explosive.
Step-back swing: step back into reverse lunge while swinging KB between legs, drive forward to stand.

tips: These are combination movements — master the individual exercises first
Lunge snatch is the hardest — start light
Great for building athletic power and coordination
Can be added to any leg day as a dynamic finisher
Credit: @sculptherbody

name: Beginner KB Full Body (@Asgooch)
description: One of the best beginner kettlebell workouts out there. One bell, four exercises, full body. From @Asgooch — great starting point for home training.

exercises.notes: Two-hand clean to rack, then squat. Explosive clean, controlled squat.
One hand at a time. Stay tall, don't lean to the loaded side.
Alternate sides. Flat back, squeeze at the top.
Feet on the kettlebell. Straight line from head to heels. Modify on knees if needed.

tips: Only need ONE kettlebell — perfect for home or travel
Start with a moderate weight you can clean comfortably
Can do as circuit (all exercises in sequence) or straight sets (4x each before moving on)
Great entry point before progressing to the cardio complex or heavy doubles
Credit: @Asgooch — link in his bio for full beginner program

name: Brutal KB Complex (@Asgooch)
description: Quick but brutal single-bell complex from @Asgooch. Swing → Squat → Row → Push Up, 10 reps each, 4 rounds. Don't put the bell down between exercises.

exercises.notes: Alternate wide (A) and narrow (B) stance each rep.
Hands on the bell handles. Elbows tucked. Last exercise — earn that rest.

tips: Don't put the bell down between exercises — that's what makes it a complex
Complexes are @Asgooch's go-to for quick but brutal workouts
If 10 reps is too much, scale to 8 or 6 per exercise
The A/B stance squat alternates wide and narrow foot positions each rep

name: Single KB Cardio Complex (@Asgooch)
description: The ultimate single-bell cardio complex from @Asgooch. Row → Clean → Squat → Snatch, 6 reps each, both sides, 5 rounds. One lighter kettlebell is all you need — he used 24kg.

exercises.notes: Left hand. Core braced, hips back, extend fully each rep.
Left hand. Hip drive into front rack, thumb on collarbone.
Left rack. Drop low, chest up, extend through quads.
Left hand. Explosive hips, punch to sky, don't bang the forearm.
Right hand. Same form — extend fully, hips back.
Right hand. Smooth clean to rack.
Right rack. Full depth, chest proud.
Right hand. Last exercise — empty the tank.

tips: Use a LIGHTER kettlebell — this is cardio, not strength. @Asgooch used 24kg.
No rest between exercises or between sides — left flows straight into right
60 seconds rest between rounds (after both sides are done)
If you're breathing heavy, you're doing it right
5 rounds total — 48 reps per side per round, 480 reps total
Great benchmark workout — track your rest times and try to reduce them

name: KB Core Library (@powerbrutehq)
description: Pick-and-choose kettlebell core exercises from @powerbrutehq. Russian twists, windmills, halos, side bends, and swings. Use as a core finisher or build your own core circuit from these.

exercises.notes: Side bend variation — or sub with KB side bends if you prefer isolation.
Windmill substitute — or do windmills if you know the movement. Slow and controlled.

tips: This is a reference library — mix and match exercises as core finishers
Russian twists: sit, lean back, rotate KB side to side
Windmills: KB overhead, hinge sideways — great for obliques and mobility
Side bends: KB in one hand, lateral flexion only
Add any of these to the end of your main kettlebell workout
Credit: @powerbrutehq

name: Daily KB Controlled Power (@metabolicfactor)
description: A daily mini-workout using a kettlebell for controlled power movements. No running, no jumping — just controlled power. Targets full-body strength, core definition, and posture. 50 circles + 60 reps of swings, pulls, and squats.
tips: No running, no jumping — just controlled power
Can be done daily as a standalone routine
Focus on smooth, controlled movements
Rest 30s between exercises if needed

name: KB Flow: Dead Clean → Squat → Lateral Lunge → Bent Press
description: A beautiful 5-move kettlebell flow from a Facebook reel. Dead clean from the floor, squat, lateral lunge, bent press overhead, then tactical clean back to start. Perform the full flow on one side, then repeat on the other. Smooth, controlled, and deceptively challenging.

exercises.notes: Open up the hips, practice rack position
Left hand. Dead stop on the floor, explosive pull to rack.
Left rack. Full depth, chest up.
Left rack. Step wide, hips back, trailing leg straight.
Left hand. Bend AWAY from the bell, lock out overhead.
Left hand. Control the descent, return to start position.
Right hand. Same form — dead stop, explosive clean.
Right rack. Step wide to the right.
Right hand. Bend torso away, lock out.

tips: This is a FLOW — all 5 exercises connect seamlessly, no pausing between moves
The bent press is the hardest part — if you're new to it, practice separately first
Use a moderate weight — this is about movement quality, not max strength
5 rounds each side = 50 total reps (25 per side)
Rest 60 seconds between rounds (after completing both sides)
Great for shoulder mobility, hip flexibility, and full-body coordination

name: Kettlebell Full Body Circuit
description: A complete full-body kettlebell circuit hitting all major muscle groups. Single bell, moderate weight.

exercises.notes: Explosive hip snap, bell to chest height
One fluid motion, squat to press

tips: Use a moderate weight - you should be able to press it for 8+ reps
Single bell for all exercises, switch hands as noted
If using double bells, reduce reps by 30%
Great for home gym or travel workouts

name: KB Gym Replacement Full Body (@Asgooch)
description: Ditch the gym membership — one or two kettlebells can replace it all. @Asgooch's 35-minute full-body session covering all movement patterns: squat, hinge, push, pull, lunge. Cardio, strength, mobility, and muscle building in one session.

exercises.notes: Easy swings to warm up the hinge

tips: All you need is one or two kettlebells to replace an entire gym
Covers all movement patterns: squat, hinge, push, pull, lunge
30-45 minutes for a better workout than most gym sessions
Credit: @Asgooch — 'ditch the gym membership and train with kettlebells'

name: Heavy Doubles Kettlebell Circuit
description: Double kettlebell work for serious strength. Heavier loads, lower reps, longer rest. Requires two kettlebells of equal weight.

exercises.notes: Single bell, wake up the hinge
Double rack. Slow and heavy. Breathe at the top.
Double press from rack. Squeeze glutes hard.
Double bells on the floor. Sumo or conventional.
One bell at a time, other stays on floor. Heavy.
Double bells. Ascending then descending reps. Rest 15s between rungs.
Flow straight into cleans — don't set bells down
Descending ladder: 3 snatches round 1, 2 round 2, 1 round 3

tips: Requires TWO kettlebells of equal weight
Pick a weight you can press 6-8 times
Quality over speed - this is a strength session
Thruster ladder: rest 15s between each rung (1 rep, rest, 2 reps, rest...)
If you only have one heavy bell, do alternating single-arm work

name: Kettlebell Legs Circuit
description: Quad and glute focused kettlebell circuit. Features the @powerbrutehq massive quads exercises plus classic KB leg work.

exercises.notes: Wake up the shoulders and core
Wide stance, chest upright, touch the bell
Flat back, squeeze glutes at top
Slow and controlled, feel the stretch
The hunched-over version from @powerbrutehq - torso stays forward. Unusual but hits posterior chain hard
Now the upright version - feel the quad burn

tips: Use a heavier bell for deadlifts/swings, moderate for squats, lighter for single-leg work
Block 4 features exercises from @powerbrutehq - the bent-over version is unusual but try it
Larger leg muscles are linked to slower aging and longer life expectancy
If you have two bells, hold one in each hand for lunges

name: Light Kettlebell Flow
description: Light single-bell work focused on movement quality, mobility, and conditioning. Higher reps, shorter rest. Great for active recovery or conditioning days.

exercises.notes: Smooth circles, warm up the shoulders
Slow descent, sit in the bottom for a beat
Crisp hip snap, let it float
Squeeze at top, control the negative

tips: Use a LIGHT bell - this is about movement quality and conditioning
Should be able to do all exercises without putting the bell down within a round
Focus on breathing and smooth transitions between exercises
Great for travel, hotel gyms, or days you don't want to go heavy

name: Moving Target Double KB Complex
description: The 'Moving Target' double kettlebell complex from @kb_kings (via @alexkaru). Swing → Clean → Snatch flowing together, with descending snatch reps each round (3-2-1). Don't set the bells down.

exercises.notes: Single bell, warm up the clean and overhead position
Flow directly into cleans — don't set bells down
Rack position, then straight into snatches
Punch through at the top. 3 snatches this round.
Same flow — swing into clean into snatch
2 snatches this round — the target is moving
1 snatch — one big explosive rep to finish

tips: Requires TWO kettlebells of equal weight
The 'moving target' = snatch reps decrease each round: 3 → 2 → 1
Do NOT set the bells down during each round — continuous flow
Master single-bell snatches before attempting double snatches
Start lighter than you think — double snatches are humbling
Rest between rounds as needed — quality over speed
Credit: @kb_kings / @alexkaru

name: KB Overhead Mobility Complex (@Asgooch)
description: Overhead and mobility focused single-bell complex from @Asgooch. Row → Snatch → OH Lunge → OH Squat → Push Press. 5 rounds, 5 reps each side. He used 24kg. Tests shoulder stability, mobility, and total-body strength.

exercises.notes: Left hand. Controlled pull, full extension.
Left hand. Explosive — bell goes straight overhead.
Left hand overhead. Keep arm locked out, torso tall.
Left hand overhead. Full depth, bell stays stacked over shoulder.
Left hand. Dip and drive — legs do the work.
Right hand. Punch through at the top.
Right hand overhead. Core braced, no arching.

tips: One kettlebell — @Asgooch used 24kg
All reps on one side before switching — no rest between exercises
The overhead squat is the hardest part — if mobility is limited, reduce depth
Snatch sets up the overhead position for lunges and squats — smooth transition
60 seconds rest between rounds (after both sides are done)
Great test of shoulder mobility and overhead stability under fatigue

name: Kettlebell Random Circuit
description: Full-body kettlebell circuit with randomized exercises. Every shuffle gives you a fresh workout - hit all major movement patterns with just one bell.
tips: Use a moderate bell you can press for 8+ reps
Shuffle for a completely new workout each time
Switch hands every set or as noted
Great for home gym or park workouts

name: The Only KB Workout You Need (@Asgooch)
description: If you're just looking to get in great shape, this is it. Single kettlebell, ~35 min, repeatable multiple times a week. Swings, clean-to-squats, chest press, and Turkish get-ups. Easy to progress — just add weight or reps.

exercises.notes: Two-handed. Explosive hips, control the descent.
Clean to rack, squat, stand. Repeat.
Lie down, press from chest. Elbows at 45 degrees.
Slow and controlled. This is practice, not a race.

tips: One kettlebell, 30-40 minutes — that's it
Hit this multiple times per week for general fitness
Progress by adding weight or reps each week
Turkish get-ups are separate skill work — take your time with them
Credit: @Asgooch — full program at kettlebellworkout.com

name: Kettlebell Upper Body Circuit
description: Push, pull, and press using kettlebells. Great for building shoulders, back, and pressing strength with a single bell.

exercises.notes: Light, wake up the posterior chain
Squeeze the shoulder blade at top
Clean is the pull, press is the push - best of both
Power from hips, shoulders stay packed
Full body push, empty the tank

tips: Use a weight you can press for at least 8 strict reps
For double kettlebell version: use two bells for presses and rows
Clean and press is the king of kettlebell exercises - focus on form
Keep rest short to build conditioning alongside strength

name: Maternity Gentle Flow
description: A safe 15-minute workout for pregnancy with gentle movements, breathing exercises, and pelvic floor work
tips: Listen to your body - modify or skip any exercise that doesn't feel right
Focus on breathing throughout - never hold your breath
Stay hydrated and take breaks as needed
Avoid exercises that cause pain, dizziness, or shortness of breath
Consult your healthcare provider before starting any exercise program during pregnancy

name: Maternity Strength Flow
description: A strength-building floor workout for pregnancy - bodyweight exercises to build muscle safely at home

exercises.notes: glute bridges, single-leg bridges, or clamshells
bodyweight squats - go as deep as comfortable
side-lying leg lifts or hip abduction
modified planks (on knees) or core stability holds
pelvic floor and deep core work

tips: Focus on controlled movements - quality over quantity
Modify exercises as needed - use wall support, reduce range of motion, or take breaks
For planks: use knees-down modification or reduce hold time
For squats: use a chair for support if needed, don't go too deep
Listen to your body - stop if you feel any pain, dizziness, or shortness of breath
Stay hydrated and breathe throughout each exercise
Consult your healthcare provider before starting any exercise program during pregnancy

name: Floor Core Classic
description: Classic floor core and bodyweight movements - preserved exactly as it was

exercises.notes: on back/shoulders, foot on floor bridge, lift each leg while holding something heavy straight up
while doing a plank move front and back
facing up, hands and heels on floor head pointed at feet, doing crunches (knee to face)

tips: Complete all exercises in a block before the rest period
Each block: 3 rounds
Bridge lifts: hold weight on hips, lift one leg at a time
Plank pulses: small forward/back movements while maintaining plank
3 legged dog: from downward dog, lift one leg, bring knee to head/nose
This is a fixed sequence - no randomization
Focus on controlled movements and core engagement

name: Morning Wakeup 4x4x3
description: Morning floor workout: 4 blocks of 4 exercises, 3 rounds each. Warmup → Floor Work → Floor Work → Core.
tips: Do this on your carpet or mat right when you wake up
4 blocks × 4 exercises × 3 rounds = 48 total exercise slots
Each block builds on the last: loosen up → activate → work → core
Breathe deeply throughout
Skip a round if short on time - you'll still get a complete session

name: Plate Abs Workout
description: Intense ab circuit using a weight plate. 4 rounds of 4 exercises, 20 reps each with 60 seconds rest between rounds.

exercises.name: Sit Up Twist
exercises.notes: Keep plate extended, control the descent, alternate sides

exercises.name: Suitcases
exercises.notes: Keep arms straight, fold knees to elbows while keeping plate extended

exercises.name: Leg Raises
exercises.notes: Press lower back into floor, lift hips slightly at top

exercises.name: Toe Touches
exercises.notes: Keep legs vertical, reach plate to toes

tips: Use moderate weight plate (10-25 lbs)
Focus on controlled movements
Great as a core finisher after main workout

name: Gentle Yoga Flow
description: Simple yoga sequence for flexibility and relaxation
tips: Move slowly and mindfully
Never force a stretch
Breathe into tight areas
